summary: The appellant, George Kitoye Roberts, was convicted on three counts of theft by the Supreme Court of the Gambia, each carrying a sentence of fifteen months' hard labour, to run concurrently, and compensation ordered under the first count. The West Africa Court of Appeal held that the three charges were alternative counts arising from the same offence, and thus only one conviction could stand. The convictions on the second and third counts were quashed, while the first was upheld. The sentence was reduced from fifteen to nine months' hard labour due to restitution by the appellant and the trial court's erroneous assumption of multiple offences. The compensation order of £15 14s. to Mrs. Eliza Andrews remained in effect.
verdict: Conviction on first count upheld; convictions on second and third counts quashed; sentence reduced

rationaleHighlights: The three theft charges were deemed alternative forms of the same offence.
Multiple convictions on alternative charges are legally impermissible.
Restitution by the appellant post-charge favored leniency.
Sentencing judge mistakenly treated one offence as three.
Appellate court affirmed one conviction to uphold accountability.
Original sentence was excessive given factual circumstances.
Compensation order was preserved as part of lawful penalty.
Appellant granted leave to appeal out of time.
